description: From Latin aberrātus, perfect passive participle of aberrō (“wander, stray or deviate from”), formed from ab (“from, away from”) + errō (“stray”).

verbs.description: aberrate (third-person singular simple present aberrates, present participle aberrating, simple past and past participle aberrated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go astray; to diverge; to deviate (from); deviate from. [mid 18th century]
examples: […]  the surfaces of the concave lens may be so proportioned as to aberrate exactly equal to the convex lens, near the axis  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive) To distort; to cause aberration of. [late 19th century]
examples: He saw them through no aberrating mist of tenderness or expediency—but with the single directness of the man of action.
